Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

Award.AbstractNarration: Recent years have witnessed a dramatic change in the goals and modus<br/>operandi of malicious hackers. In particular, hackers realized the<br/>potential monetary gains associated with Internet fraud. As a result,<br/>there has been an integration of sophisticated computer attacks with<br/>well-established fraud mechanisms devised by organized crime. This<br/>process has created a vibrant underground economy.<br/><br/>Recent research has mostly focused on the visible aspects of the<br/>underground economy, such as botnets, spam, and phishing. However,<br/>little has been done to understand this economy as a whole and to<br/>analyze and model its characteristics. What is needed is a holistic<br/>approach to the study and analysis of the underground economy that<br/>includes all aspects of the criminal process. In this project, novel<br/>techniques and tools are developed that help to analyze the<br/>underground economy and obtain a comprehensive picture of the complete<br/>criminal process. More precisely, the underground economy is analyzed<br/>and modeled from two different vantage points: First, the analysis<br/>identifies the actors participating the underground economy and models<br/>their different roles. Second, the analysis examines the<br/>infrastructure that is used by criminals to carry out their<br/>operations.<br/><br/>The results of this project are techniques and tools to gather<br/>information about the infrastructure of the underground economy and<br/>the involved actors. The broader impact is a reduction in the amount<br/>and severity of crime performed in the Internet. Moreover, the results<br/>of this project support the task of cyber crime law enforcement in<br/>their fight against the underground economy.<br/>
